title: When do we use the negative square root? - Quora

response.answer_text: That’s an ambiguous question. One interpretation is how do you get negative square roots. The answer is that they come automatically. When you look for the square root of 4, for example, you’re asking for a number that gives 4 when squared. There are two such numbers, 2 and -2. Every positive number has two square roots, equal in magnitude, one positive, one negative. The other interpretation is what is the square root of a negative number. In the ordinary real numbers, there isn’t any. You’re asking for a number whose square is negative, but the square of any real number is positive. Mathematicians invented imaginary numbers to solve that problem. The number i is the square root of -1. Actually, -1 has two square roots, i and -i. If you want the square root of -4, the answer is 2i and -2i. How do you do negative square roots?
